title: [K-12] Problem-Based Collaborative Learning for Developing Scientific Literacy and Language Reasoning Skills: Text and Speech Data Analysis and Investigative Writing

context.prior_knowledge: Basic science concepts (variable control, hypothesis formulation) and college-level language proficiency (grammar/vocabulary analysis, text interpretation, discourse structure understanding)
context.additional_context: A graduate-level language course conducting project-based assessments in smartphone-centric, resource-limited environments. Learners analyze language data collected via mobile devices (conversation recordings, SNS texts) with a focus on activities combining scientific inquiry methods (observation-measurement-conclusion) and linguistic analysis (text structure-pragmatic context).

learning_goals: Learners analyze complex linguistic data (text/audio) to generate scientific hypotheses and systematically present linguistic evidence (grammar/lexical patterns).
Through collaborative problem-solving with peers, learners strengthen critical reading skills and argumentation structures by collecting and evaluating evidence from linguistic materials.

After observing three real-language phenomena (conversations/texts), learners define two problems and generate one inquiry question per case, then write a 500-character exploratory draft integrating expressive and analytical skills.

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
